Chapter:
Residue-Class-Wise Affine Mappings, Groups and Monoids over &ZZ;^2
gap> SizeScreen([75,24]);;
This chapter describes how to compute with residue-class-wise affine mappings of &ZZ;^2 and with groups and monoids formed by them.
The rings on which we have defined residue-class-wise affine mappings so far have all been principal ideal domains, and it has been crucial that all nontrivial principal ideals had finite index. However, the rings &ZZ;^d, d > 1 are not principal ideal domains. Furthermore, their principal ideals have infinite index. Therefore as moduli of residue-class-wise affine mappings we can only use lattices of full rank, for these are precisely the ideals of &ZZ;^d of finite index. However, on the other hand we can also be more permissive and look at &ZZ;^d not only as a ring, but also as a free &ZZ;-module. The consequence of this is that then an affine mapping of &ZZ;^d is not just given by v \mapsto (av+b)/c for some a, b, c \in &ZZ;^d, but rather by v \mapsto (vA+b)/c, where A \in &ZZ;^{d \times d}.
The definition of residue-class-wise affine mappings of &ZZ;^d
rcwa mapping
Let d \in &NN;. We call a mapping f: &ZZ;^d \rightarrow &ZZ;^d residue-class-wise affine if there is a lattice L = &ZZ;^d M where M \in &ZZ;^{d \times d} is a matrix of full rank, such that the restrictions of f to the residue classes r + L \in &ZZ;^d/L are all affine. This means that for any residue class r + L \in &ZZ;^d/L, there is a matrix A_{r+L} \in &ZZ;^{d \times d}, a vector b_{r+L} \in &ZZ;^d and a positive integer c_{r+L} such that the restriction of f to r + L is given by f|_{r + L}: \ r + L \ \rightarrow \ &ZZ;^d, \ \ v \ \mapsto \ (v \cdot A_{r+L} + b_{r+L})/c_{r+L}. For reasons of uniqueness, we assume that L is chosen maximal with respect to inclusion, and that no prime factor of c_{r+L} divides all coefficients of A_{r+L} and b_{r+L}.
rcwa mapping
rcwa mapping
class-wise translating
prime set
We call the lattice L the modulus of f, written Mod(f). Further we define the prime set of f as the set of all primes which divide the determinant of at least one of the coefficients A_{r+L} or which divide the determinant of M, and we call the mapping f class-wise translating if all coefficients A_{r+L} are identity matrices and all coefficients c_{r+L} are equal to 1.
For the sake of simplicity, we identify a lattice with the Hermite normal form of the matrix by whose rows it is spanned.
Entering residue-class-wise affine mappings of &ZZ;^2
Residue-class-wise affine mappings of &ZZ;^2 can be entered using the general constructor
or the more specialized functions , and . The arguments differ only slightly.
RcwaMapping (the general constructor; methods for &ZZ;^2)
An rcwa mapping of &ZZ;^2.
The above methods return
(a)
the rcwa mapping of R = Integers^2 with modulus L and coefficients coeffs,
(b)
a bijective rcwa mapping which induces a bijection between the partitions P1 and P2 of &ZZ;^2 into residue classes and which is affine on the elements of P1,
(c)
a bijective rcwa mapping with residue class cycles given by a list cycles of lists of pairwise disjoint residue classes of &ZZ;^2 each of which it permutes cyclically, and
(d)
the rcwa mapping of &ZZ;^2 whose projections to the coordinates are given by f and g,
respectively.
The modulus of an rcwa mapping of &ZZ;^2 is a lattice of full rank. It is represented by a matrix L in Hermite normal form, whose rows are the spanning vectors.
A coefficient list for an rcwa mapping of &ZZ;^2 with modulus L consists of |\det(L)| coefficient triples [A_{r+&ZZ;^2L}, b_{r+&ZZ;^2L}, c_{r+&ZZ;^2L}]. The entries A_{r+&ZZ;^2L} are 2 \times 2 integer matrices, the b_{r+&ZZ;^2L} are elements of &ZZ;^2, i.e. lists of two integers, and the c_{r+&ZZ;^2L} are integers. The ordering of the coefficient triples is determined by the ordering of the representatives of the residue classes r+&ZZ;^2L in the sorted list returned by AllResidues(Integers^2,L).
The methods for the operation RcwaMapping perform a number of argument checks, which can be skipped by using RcwaMappingNC instead.
Last but not least, regarding Method (d) it should be mentioned that only very special rcwa mappings of &ZZ;^2 have projections to coordinates.

ClassTransposition (for &ZZ;^2)
The class transposition \tau_{r_1+&ZZ;^2L_1,r_2+&ZZ;^2L_2}.
Let d \in &NN;, and let L_1, L_2 \in &ZZ;^{d \times d} be matrices of full rank which are in Hermite normal form. Further let r_1 + &ZZ;^d L_1 and r_2 + &ZZ;^d L_2 be disjoint residue classes, and assume that the representatives r_1 and r_2 are reduced modulo &ZZ;^d L_1 and &ZZ;^d L_2, respectively. Then we define the class transposition \tau_{r_1+&ZZ;^d L_1, r_2+&ZZ;^d L_2} \in {\rm Sym}(&ZZ;^d) as the involution which interchanges r_1 + k L_1 and r_2 + k L_2 for all k \in &ZZ;^d.
The class transposition \tau_{r_1+&ZZ;^d L_1, r_2+&ZZ;^d L_2} interchanges the residue classes r_1+&ZZ;^d L_1 and r_2+&ZZ;^d L_2, and fixes the complement of their union pointwise. The set of all class transpositions of &ZZ;^d generates the simple group CT(&ZZ;^d) (cf. ).
TransposedClasses
In the four-argument form, the arguments r1, L1, r2 and L2 stand for r_1, L_1, r_2 and L_2, respectively. In the two-argument form, the arguments cl1 and cl2 stand for the residue classes r_1+&ZZ;^2 L_1 and r_2+&ZZ;^2 L_2, respectively. Enclosing the argument list in list brackets is permitted. The residue classes r_1+&ZZ;^2 L_1 and r_2+&ZZ;^2 L_2 are stored as an attribute TransposedClasses.
SplittedClassTransposition
There is also a method for SplittedClassTransposition available for class transpositions of &ZZ;^2. This method takes as first argument the class transposition, and as second argument a list of two integers. These integers are the numbers of parts into which the class transposition is to be sliced in each dimension. Note that the product of the returned class transpositions is not always equal to the class transposition passed as first argument. However this equality holds if the first entry of the second argument is 1.
gap> ct := ClassTransposition([0,0],[[2,1],[0,2]],[1,0],[[2,1],[0,4]]); ClassTransposition((0,0)+(2,1)Z+(0,2)Z,(1,0)+(2,1)Z+(0,4)Z) gap> Display(ct);

ClassRotation (for &ZZ;^2)
The class rotation \rho_{r(m),u}.
Let d \in &NN;. Given a residue class r+&ZZ;^dL and a matrix u \in {\rm GL}(d,&ZZ;), the class rotation \rho_{r+&ZZ;^dL,u} is the rcwa mapping which maps v \in r+&ZZ;^dL to vu + r(1-u) and which fixes &ZZ;^d \setminus r+&ZZ;^dL pointwise.
RotationFactor
In the two-argument form, the argument cl stands for the residue class r+&ZZ;^dL. Enclosing the argument list in list brackets is permitted. The argument u is stored as an attribute RotationFactor.

ClassShift (for &ZZ;^2)
The class shift \nu_{r+&ZZ;^dL,k}.
Let d \in &NN;. Given a residue class r+&ZZ;^dL and an integer k \in \{1, \dots, d\}, the class shift \nu_{r+&ZZ;^dL,k} is the rcwa mapping which maps v \in r+&ZZ;^dL to v + L_k and which fixes &ZZ;^d \setminus r+&ZZ;^dL pointwise. Here L_k denotes the kth row of L.
In the two-argument form, the argument cl stands for the residue class r+&ZZ;^dL. Enclosing the argument list in list brackets is permitted.

The projections of the rcwa mapping f of &ZZ;^2 to the coordinates if such projections exist, and fail otherwise.
An rcwa mapping can be projected to the first / second coordinate if and only if the first / second coordinate of the image of a point depends only on the first / second coordinate of the preimage. Note that this is a very strong and restrictive condition.

Residue-class-wise affine groups over &ZZ;^2 can be entered by Group, GroupByGenerators and GroupWithGenerators, like any groups in &GAP;. Likewise, residue-class-wise affine monoids over &ZZ;^2 can be entered by Monoid and MonoidByGenerators. The groups RCWA(&ZZ;^2) and CT(&ZZ;^2) are entered as RCWA(Integers^2) and CT(Integers^2), respectively. The monoid Rcwa(&ZZ;^2) is entered as Rcwa(Integers^2).

There are methods for which embed the groups SL(2,&ZZ;) and GL(2,&ZZ;) into RCWA(&ZZ;^2) in such a way that the support of the image is a specified residue class:
IsomorphismRcwaGroup (Embeddings of SL(2,&ZZ;) and GL(2,&ZZ;))
A monomorphism from sl2z respectively gl2z to RCWA(&ZZ;^2), such that the support of the image is the residue class cl and the generators are affine on cl.

DrawOrbitPicture
The function can also be used to depict orbits under the action of rcwa groups over &ZZ;^2. Further there is a function which depicts residue class unions of &ZZ;^2 and partitions of &ZZ;^2 into such:
DrawGrid
Nothing.
This function depicts the residue class union U of &ZZ;^2 or the partition P of &ZZ;^2 into residue class unions, respectively. The arguments yrange and xrange are the coordinate ranges of the rectangular snippet to be drawn, and the argument filename is the name, i.e. the full path name, of the output file. If the first argument is a residue class union, the output picture is black-and-white, where black pixels represent members of U and white pixels represent non-members. If the first argument is a partition of &ZZ;^2 into residue class unions, the produced picture is colored, and different colors are used to denote membership in different parts.
